Their historical pathways, whether land-grant or scrip-grant, carry different patterns of complicity, and, as the data reveal, profoundly different patterns of accountability.

title: Uncovering the Patterns of Repatriation: A Multi-Lens Exploration
text:
Figure 3.3 - Cumulative Growth of Universities by Grant Type
This interactive line chart tracks the cumulative number of universities over time, categorized by their grant type: land-grant universities and scrip-grant universities. By hovering over any point on the lines, users can view the exact year and the total cumulative number of universities established by that point in time.

title: Uncovering the Patterns of Repatriation: A Multi-Lens Exploration
text:
The visualization reveals two important trends. First, scrip-grant universities began appearing earlier and expanded steadily, reflecting early patterns of land commodification through sale rather than direct use. Second, the passage of the Morrill Act in 1862 triggered a rapid proliferation of land-grant universities, marking a new phase of state-supported expansion deeply tied to Indigenous dispossession.
Together, these patterns tell a deeper story: as universities expanded, often through lands appropriated from Native nations, their obligations toward repatriation deepened.


Figure 3.4 - Historical Profile of Land-Grant and Scrip-Grant Universities
This interactive dual-panel visualization offers two complementary views of university histories and their repatriation efforts. On the left, a box plot displays the distribution of founding years for land-grant and scrip-grant universities. Hovering over each box reveals the minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum founding years—enabling close comparison of institutional timelines. On the right, a donut chart shows the proportion of total university repatriations by grant type. The two panels are linked: clicking a grant type in the legend will filter the donut chart accordingly, allowing users to isolate and examine repatriation patterns specific to land-grant or scrip-grant institutions.

title: Uncovering the Patterns of Repatriation: A Multi-Lens Exploration
text:
Building on the cumulative history, this visualization examines how land-grant and scrip-grant universities differ in their historical foundations and repatriation engagement.
The box plot shows that land-grant universities cluster tightly around the late 19th century, consistent with the immediate impact of the Morrill Act. Scrip-grant universities, by contrast, span a broader historical range, some founded as early as the late 18th century.
Meanwhile, the donut chart on the right reveals a striking asymmetry. A full 98% of documented university repatriations—1,358 in total—originate from land-grant institutions. In contrast, scrip-grant universities account for only 28 repatriations, despite their historical accumulation of wealth through land sales.
Together, these charts highlight a powerful asymmetry. Land-grant universities, built directly atop appropriated Indigenous territories, have begun addressing their responsibilities. Scrip-grant universities, though equally tied to colonial land extraction, largely remain absent from this moral reckoning..


Figure 3.5 - University Establishment vs. Historical Endowment and Repatriation Efforts
This interactive bubble plot visualizes universities based on three dimensions: their founding year (x-axis), their historical endowment in 1914 (y-axis, log scale), and the number of repatriated individuals (bubble size). By hovering over each bubble, users can view detailed information for each university, including its name, year founded, historical endowment, total repatriated individuals, and annual repatriation rate.

title: Uncovering the Patterns of Repatriation: A Multi-Lens Exploration
text:
Zooming further into individual institutions, this plot maps universities by founding year, historical endowment (as of 1914), and repatriation activity.
Among all institutions, only Michigan State University, Kansas State University, and Washington State University stand out with significantly larger bubbles, reflecting active repatriation efforts. In contrast, the vast majority of universities form a cloud of much smaller circles, indicating zero recorded repatriated individuals and an annual repatriation rate of zero.
This visualization highlights an uncomfortable truth: although many universities benefited historically from substantial land-based endowments, especially those established under the Morrill Act, most have made little to no effort toward repatriating Native ancestors. The landscape of responsibility is highly uneven, raising critical questions about historical accountability and institutional inertia.


Figure 3.6 - Additional Combine Analysis: Pace of Expansion vs. Depth of Accountability
This combined visualization of Figure 3.3 and Figure 3.5 allows you to explore university repatriation histories from two interconnected perspectives: time and scale. On the same plot, bubble sizes represent the number of individuals repatriated by each university, while the dotted lines track the cumulative number of institutions established by grant type—land or scrip. By clicking on the legend, you can isolate either grant type, filtering the view to show only land-grant or scrip-grant universities. The legend also allows toggling between the bubble plot and the cumulative trend lines, offering flexible perspectives on institutional growth and responsibility.

title: Uncovering the Patterns of Repatriation: A Multi-Lens Exploration
text:
To conclude our institutional analysis and offer an integrated perspective, this unified view brings together two key narratives of university history—the pace of expansion and the depth of accountability. Together, they underscore the enduring gap between institutional growth and the moral reckoning still required.


Our institutional analysis exposes a landscape of uneven reckoning.
Universities, especially land-grant institutions founded through the Morrill Act, emerge both as primary beneficiaries of Indigenous dispossession and as key actors—however imperfect—in the repatriation movement. Museums, historical centers, and federal agencies also shoulder significant responsibilities, though with widely varying levels of engagement.
Yet across all types and histories, one truth echoes: the moral debt incurred through the acquisition of Native lands and ancestors has not yet been fully paid. The act of repatriation is not simply a matter of policy compliance, but a profound act of justice and healing. It demands not occasional gestures, but sustained, institutionalized commitment—rooted in historical understanding and ethical responsibility.
As we move forward, the question remains: Will institutions confront not only their collections, but their origins—and choose to become sites of repair rather than silence?

title: Uncovering the Patterns of Repatriation: A Multi-Lens Exploration
text:
The passage of NAGPRA in 1990 marked a legal commitment to the repatriation of Native American remains and cultural heritage. However, the pace and pattern of repatriation have varied significantly over time. In this section, we examine how repatriation efforts have unfolded year by year, focusing not only on total numbers but also on the different categories of items being returned—such as individuals, funerary objects, sacred items, and cultural patrimony. Through these trends, we reveal how policy changes, institutional actions, and historical reckonings have shaped the tempo of justice.





Figure 1.1 - Repatriation by Year
This visualization is an interactive line chart that allows users to explore the repatriation trends by different object categories. By selecting from the dropdown menu on the right—such as Individuals, Funerary Objects, Sacred Objects, or Cultural Patrimony—you can dynamically update the chart to focus on specific types of repatriated items. This functionality enables a deeper, comparative exploration of how different categories have contributed to the overall patterns of repatriation across time.





This interactive line chart visualizes the total number of repatriated items each year since NAGPRA’s enactment. A key pattern is the dramatic peak in 2024, with over 1.73 million items repatriated—significantly higher than any previous year. This spike corresponds to the implementation of updated NAGPRA regulations under the Biden administration, alongside intensified institutional efforts, reflecting growing federal pressure and moral accountability.



This chart shows the number of Native American ancestral remains repatriated annually. Two major peaks stand out—one around 1998, and a larger one in 2023. The first surge follows a collaborative effort between the U.S. Navy and the Bishop Museum to return over 3,000 ancestral remains from Mokapu Peninsula, Oʻahu. The second peak reflects the Tennessee Valley Authority’s return of over 4,800 remains in 2023, which is one of the largest NAGPRA actions in the region. These spikes signal how institutional collaboration and legal pressure can translate into large-scale restitutions of ancestral dignity.



This chart reveals a dramatic increase in the number of funerary objects returned in 2024, largely driven by Sacramento State’s repatriation of over 1.28 million items following a campus-wide investigation. The magnitude of this return underscores both the scale of past accumulation and the power of institutional accountability in response to scrutiny and new federal guidance.



This chart illustrates the annual count of unassociated funerary objects—those not clearly tied to specific individuals. A pronounced spike in 2017 marks the reporting of over 55,000 such items by the Army Corps of Engineers, from a 1961 excavation in South Dakota later linked to the Yankton Sioux Tribe. The return of these objects, despite uncertain provenance, reflects an ethical shift toward restitution even in the absence of complete documentation.



This chart tracks the number of sacred items returned each year under NAGPRA. A notable spike occurs in 2005, when the National Park Service facilitated the repatriation of sacred objects from Chaco Culture National Historical Park to the Pueblo of Zia. Although the numbers remain relatively low, each instance holds immense spiritual significance, often requiring deep consultation and ceremonial respect, which makes every return a powerful act of cultural restoration.



This chart highlights the return of items classified as cultural patrimony—those of collective importance to tribal nations. A peak in 2024 corresponds with Sacramento State’s return of remains and funerary objects originally taken in 1978. These items, representing communal heritage rather than individual ownership, symbolize a deeper institutional recognition of Indigenous cultural sovereignty and the need to reconcile with long-ignored histories.



This chart shows the number of items repatriated each year that were identified as both sacred objects and cultural patrimony—dual-classification categories under NAGPRA. A distinct peak appears in 2024, when the Oakland Museum of California announced the return of 332 such items. This case stands out not only for its volume, but also for its complexity: dual-tagged objects often embody both ceremonial and communal significance, making their classification and rightful return especially meaningful. This moment represents one of the largest and most symbolically layered repatriation efforts under NAGPRA to date.


Figure 1.2 - Repatriation by Year with Breakdown
This interactive visualization consists of two linked components: the upper line chart displays the total number of repatriated items by year, while the lower bar chart provides a detailed breakdown of repatriated item types (e.g., Individuals, Funerary Objects, Unassociated Funerary Objects, Sacred Objects, Cultural Patrimony, and Dual-Classified Items) for a selected year. Clicking on a specific year in the line chart dynamically updates the bar chart below, allowing viewers to explore how the composition of repatriated items varies year by year.




Across most years, funerary objects consistently represent the largest share of repatriated items, reflecting the historical prevalence of funerary artifacts in institutional holdings. Although there are fluctuations, funerary objects overwhelmingly dominate repatriation activity compared to other categories like sacred objects or cultural patrimony. This pattern highlights an ongoing need to address broader categories of Indigenous cultural heritage in repatriation efforts.


The temporal trends reveal a long period of stagnation, punctuated by a recent and dramatic increase in repatriation activity, particularly in 2023 and 2024. These shifts align with regulatory reform, public pressure, and growing ethical accountability. However, the data also expose decades of institutional inertia and missed opportunities. While the upward trend offers hope, it also calls for sustained and comprehensive commitment. Repatriation must not be a one-time surge, but a continuous, institutionalized practice of justice and healing, and one that fully addresses all categories of Indigenous cultural heritage.
